steps.title: Your Brain's Superpower
steps.narration: Imagine your brain had no memory. Every second, you'd forget everythingâ€”your name, where you are, what you were doing. You couldn't think at all!

steps.title: Computers Face the Same Challenge
steps.narration: Computers are exactly the same. Before they can do anything useful, they need a way to remember things. That's where variables come in.

steps.title: Variables: Labeled Boxes
steps.narration: A variable is like a labeled box. You put something in the box, give it a name, and later you can ask 'Hey, what's in the box called score?' and the computer remembers.

steps.title: Example: player_name
steps.narration: Let's create a variable called player underscore name and store the text 'Alex' inside. Now anytime we need the player's name, we just look in that box!

steps.title: Example: score
steps.narration: We can also create a variable called score and set it to zero. As the player earns points, we update what's in the box. The computer always remembers the latest value.

steps.title: Example: is_playing
steps.narration: And here's is underscore playing set to True. This tells the computer whether the game is currently running. Variables can hold text, numbers, or true-false values!

steps.title: Using Variables
steps.narration: When you use a variable in your code, Python looks in the box and gets whatever value is stored there. You've just learned the first superpower of programming: giving your computer memory!

questions.question: What is a variable in programming?
options: A labeled container that stores data
questions.explanation: A variable is like a labeled box where you store information. You give it a name (the label) and put a value inside.

questions.question: In Python, what does player_name = "Alex" do?
options: Creates a box labeled 'player_name' and stores 'Alex' inside
Asks the user for their name
questions.explanation: The = sign in Python puts the value on the right into the variable on the left. So player_name = "Alex" stores the text 'Alex' in a variable called player_name.

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a valid thing to store in a variable?
options: All of these CAN be stored in variables
questions.explanation: Variables can store many types of data including text (strings), numbers (integers and floats), and boolean values (True/False). That's what makes them so powerful!
